config.templateName: Corriedale Ovine Brain Atlas of Liyanage et al. (2015)
config.slicePositionDescription: posterior(-) or anterior(+) distance to origin
aboutHtml: Brain atlases play a central role in neuroscientific and clinical practice, and are a prerequisite for studying brain networks across scales. Many current human brain atlases only cover specific structures, lack fine-grained parcellations, and fail to provide functionally important connectivity information. The Brainnetome Atlas (BNA) is built upon a connectivity-based parcellation framework, derived from non-invasive multimodal neuroimaging techniques.

The atlas has the following features:
  1. It establishes a fine-grained brain parcellation scheme for 210 cortical, 36 subcortical and 28 cerebellar regions.
  2. It supplies a detailed map of anatomical and functional connections.
  3. It decodes brain functions using a meta-analytical approach.
  4. It is an open resource for researchers to use for the analysis of whole brain parcellations, connections, and functions.

The BNA has been created at the Brainnetome Center, Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences. To facilitate future investigations in healthy and pathological states, the atlas and accompanying software is made freely available for download.

definingCitations.title: The Human Brainnetome Atlas: A New Brain Atlas Based on Connectional Architecture.
